name: AnchorWatch

faqs.q: How does AnchorWatch's Trident vault insurance work?
faqs.a: AnchorWatch locks each deposit inside a Trident 2-of-3 multisig vault that maps to a Lloyd's-backed policy, so coverage follows the exact UTXO you fund. If you permanently lose control under the policy terms, you can file a claim instead of eating the loss.

faqs.q: What does AnchorWatch charge for custody insurance?
faqs.a: Premiums run roughly 0.55%–2% of the insured value per year and are paid up front in USD. A Trident Services Fee of up to 0.25% annually (first $250k waived) is billed monthly so you can size coverage to your treasury.

faqs.q: How fast can I move bitcoin out of an AnchorWatch vault?
faqs.a: You prepare and sign the spend in Trident, submit your evidence package, and AnchorWatch usually clears compliance plus its signature within one to two business days. Plan larger withdrawals ahead so insurance controls never become a surprise bottleneck.

faqs.q: Does AnchorWatch require KYC and where is it available?
faqs.a: Yes. AnchorWatch underwrites regulated US policies, so onboarding requires identity documents or KYB packages and they currently insure only US-based clients.

faqs.q: How are customer keys and funds segregated at AnchorWatch?
faqs.a: You generate your own keys on factory-sealed devices, and each vault has a unique output descriptor that proves funds are never commingled with other policyholders. You can verify segregation on-chain before depositing sats.

description:
AnchorWatch is a U.S.-based bitcoin custody and insurance provider trying to bridge traditional insurance with Bitcoin-native custody, delivering peace of mind by offering an elegant, turnkey solution for long-term bitcoin holders and corporate treasuries seeking secure, insured, and inheritance-ready custody.

What separates AnchorWatch is their unique integration of protocol-level multisig vaults with time-locked recovery and insurance. Users hold a multi-signature key set alongside AnchorWatch; both are required to sign transactions, and over time additional recovery mechanisms activate to handle key-loss, death, or coercion scenarios.

User reviews and discussions (e.g. from the Build With Bitcoin transcript) emphasize AnchorWatch's layered approach: the combination of vault tech and insurance addresses both technical and human vulnerabilities. The service also supports inheritance planning—time-locked access for heirs without cumbersome "treasure maps". This focus on estate continuity is cited as a major differentiator, especially for non-technical beneficiaries.

Their future vision includes expanding beyond U.S. customers, offering bespoke large-value enterprise policies, and exploring Bitcoin-denominated insurance.

tl_dr.best_for: AnchorWatch pairs Trident multisig vaults with Lloyd's-backed insurance so US treasuries and families can keep keys cold without giving up coverage. Choose it when you want estate, audit, and compliance workflows around long-term bitcoin.
tl_dr.consider_if: The service adds a compliance desk to every spend, which means you must plan withdrawals ahead of time. Consider it if you want that oversight plus access to insurance-grade recovery tooling.
tl_dr.not_ideal_when: Because AnchorWatch must sign each spend, you trade speed for assurance. It's not ideal when you need instant, global, or anonymous control.

steps.title: 1. Choose policy & secure keys
actions: Meet AnchorWatch underwriting, review coverage tiers, and set the USD limit you want insured.
Complete KYC or KYB, sign the engagement letter, and receive the factory-sealed signing devices they ship.
Generate your customer keys during the onboarding call so AnchorWatch never sees the seed material.
steps.gotcha: Insurance underwriting requires US residency or entity registration plus identity verification.

steps.title: 2. Build and test the vault
actions: Configure the Trident miniscript policy, label each signer, and review the vault's output descriptor together.
Send a small test deposit, confirm it on your own node, and log the insured UTXO ID provided in the policy.
Document the recovery script and store redundant copies offline for board reviews.
steps.gotcha: Skipping the descriptor review means you cannot independently prove the vault's policy later.

steps.title: 3. Operationalize compliance & inheritance
actions: Define compliance contacts so AnchorWatch knows who can request co-signatures and who gets alerts.
Set withdrawal workflows, including evidence AnchorWatch needs before it signs and the one-to-two business day window.
Add beneficiaries or board-approved heirs in Trident so inheritance and insurance claims share paperwork.
steps.gotcha: Transactions requested outside the documented workflow are delayed until compliance can verify them.

micro_faqs.q: Do I have to use Trident to be insured by AnchorWatch?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. The insurance is bound to Trident's miniscript vault so AnchorWatch can verify keys and sign when policy terms are met.

micro_faqs.q: How fast does AnchorWatch co-sign transactions?
micro_faqs.a: After you sign and submit supporting evidence, AnchorWatch usually completes compliance checks and adds its signature within one to two business days.

micro_faqs.q: What if every customer key is lost?
micro_faqs.a: AnchorWatch can invoke the time-locked recovery path with its emergency partner, or you can file a claim that covers the permanent loss if policy conditions are met.

key_features.heading: Your insured policy (who signs and when)

features.title: Insurance-backed Trident vaults
bullets: Who holds keys: You keep two customer-controlled devices, AnchorWatch keeps its own signer set, and an emergency partner stays offline until needed.
Policy terms: Each insured vault corresponds to a specific UTXO and policy number, so loss calculations stay 1:1.
When it signs: AnchorWatch co-signs once compliance evidence is reviewed, typically within one to two business days.
features.footer: Good for: Long-term storage that needs institutional approvals. Trade-off: Movements wait on AnchorWatch availability.

features.title: Time-locked recovery script
bullets: Miniscript path: Trident encodes a timelock that lets AnchorWatch and its emergency partner rebuild access if customer keys disappear.
Recovery script: You receive descriptors so you can spend through Bitcoin Core even if Trident is offline.
Insurance tie-in: Manual recovery can avoid deductibles and keep coverage intact.
features.footer: Good for: Estate planning or key-loss response. Trade-off: Timelocks add waiting periods before funds move.

recovery_heading: If this happens, can I still move my Bitcoin?

recovery_explainers.why: Trident is 2-of-3, so you and AnchorWatch still have a quorum if one customer device fails.
how: Notify AnchorWatch support and document when the device was lost or destroyed.
Schedule a replacement call so they can ship a new sealed signer and walk you through key generation.
Update the vault records and insurance schedule so the new key is reflected.
recovery_explainers.gotcha: AnchorWatch needs evidence that the lost key cannot be recovered before issuing new hardware.

recovery_explainers.why: You hold the recovery script and descriptors, so a timelock path lets you spend without AnchorWatch if they are unreachable.
how: Load the recovery script into Bitcoin Core or another compatible wallet.
Wait for the policy's timelock window, then use your remaining keys plus the emergency partner to co-sign.
Sweep funds to a destination you control and notify AnchorWatch once channels reopen.
recovery_explainers.gotcha: Bypassing AnchorWatch during an outage may impact insurance, so log every step and inform them once possible.

recovery_explainers.why: AnchorWatch will not sign until compliance clears the request, giving you time to halt a coerced withdrawal and trigger insurance steps.
how: Refuse to sign the outgoing transaction and alert AnchorWatch via their emergency contact.
Provide incident evidence (police report, affidavits) so they can freeze signatures.
Work with them to either rebuild access via the recovery partner or initiate a claim if keys were compromised.
recovery_explainers.gotcha: Policies require timely reporting of coercion events; delays can affect coverage.

recovery_explainers.why: A miniscript time-locked path plus AnchorWatch's emergency signer lets them rebuild control, and the insurance policy covers any permanent loss that remains.
how: Report the loss immediately and provide documentation proving the keys are unrecoverable.
AnchorWatch and the emergency partner wait out the preset timelock, then co-sign a recovery spend.
If recovery fails, AnchorWatch files the Lloyd's-backed claim on your behalf using your evidence packet.
recovery_explainers.gotcha: Claims include a 10% or 25% deductible, so full reimbursement depends on the policy option you selected.

inheritance.intro: Insurance paperwork and vault workflows align so heirs are not guessing when the time comes.

cards.title: 1. Stage the policy
cards.why: Beneficiaries need to be named inside Trident and on the policy so compliance can verify them later.
steps: Gather legal documents (trust, corporate resolutions) before the onboarding call.
List beneficiaries or board designees in Trident and in the insurance schedule.
Store recovery scripts plus instructions in separate, access-controlled locations.
Review the plan annually with AnchorWatch so contacts and documents stay current.
cards.action: Do this: Align legal paperwork, Trident assignments, and insurance records at the same time.

cards.title: 2. Inheritance-ready claims
cards.prereqs: Beneficiary identity docs · Recovery script · Policy paperwork
steps: Beneficiary contacts AnchorWatch with proof of death or corporate instruction.
AnchorWatch triggers its compliance review and informs Lloyd's if a claim is likely.
Once the waiting period clears, AnchorWatch co-signs or releases instructions so heirs can move funds.
Any deductible is applied before remaining sats settle to the beneficiary-controlled vault.
cards.timeline: Expect compliance plus insurer review before coins move; publish timelines in corporate policy manuals.
cards.action: Do this: Keep beneficiaries in the loop so they know how to contact AnchorWatch when needed.

cards.title: 3. If plans break

scenarios.path: AnchorWatch pauses signatures until replacement affidavits arrive.
Board minutes or court orders must clarify who controls the account before funds move.
Execute the recovery script via timelock, then present records once service resumes.

cards.action: Do this: Record fallback contacts plus emergency communication channels in your continuity binder.

compatibility.intro: Know which hardware, browsers, and standards the Trident vault expects before underwriting.

items.notes: Factory-sealed hardware shipped during onboarding; kept offline except when signing.

items.name: Customer-provided HSMs
items.notes: Custom setups require AnchorWatch review so the policy still tracks signatures.

platforms.name: Mobile browsers
platforms.notes: Monitoring only; signing happens on dedicated hardware.

methods.constraint: Signing devices stay air-gapped except when exchanging PSBT files.
Use the output descriptor to watch the vault from your own node.
Web-based evidence uploads with audit logging

table.notes: Customer devices use standard seed phrases
Hierarchical deterministic derivation for vault paths
Customers receive descriptors for independent verification

descriptors.notes: AnchorWatch emails descriptors plus Recovery Script during onboarding

psbt.notes: PSBT handoffs move between Trident, customer devices, and AnchorWatch

derivation_paths.notes: Policy-specific paths documented inside the recovery script

output_descriptors.notes: Used for on-chain audits and cold recovery drills

costs.intro: AnchorWatch bills like an insurance carrier: premiums are paid up front, while the Trident Services Fee covers custody tech and support.

summary_stats.upfront: Premium: 0.55%–2% of insured value (paid in USD)
summary_stats.monthly: TSF: up to 0.25% annually after the first $250k
summary_stats.per_transaction: Compliance signing: one transaction per quarter included

items.name: Annual insurance premium
items.note: Paid at policy start in USD

tiles.title: What AnchorWatch collects & where it lives
tiles.benefit: Keys stay offline Segregated records
tiles.why: Insurance carriers need KYC data and policy evidence, but key material never leaves your hardware.
tiles.summary: AnchorWatch stores identity docs, policy forms, and transaction evidence on US servers with audit logs. Signing keys remain on the devices you control, and descriptors plus recovery scripts live in the secure portal you download during onboarding.
bullets: Stays on devices: Customer seed phrases · AnchorWatch signer keys · Hardware PINs
Customer portal: Recovery scripts · Output descriptors · Audit-ready statements
AnchorWatch servers: KYC/KYB packets · Insurance paperwork · Compliance evidence
Logs: Signer requests · Support tickets · Claim documentation
tiles.explainer_summary: Can I audit my stored data?
tiles.explainer_text: Yes. The Trident portal lets you download policy records plus descriptors anytime, and AnchorWatch will export or delete KYC records once regulatory retention windows expire.

tiles.title: Jurisdiction: what that means for you
tiles.benefit: US-regulated Lloyd's backing
tiles.why: Policies are written on Lloyd's of London paper but administered from the US, so American insurance law applies.
tiles.summary: AnchorWatch must respond to lawful US data or subpoena requests and keeps complaint channels through Arch Insurance and Lloyd's. Insurance coverage extends only to US persons or entities today, so cross-border clients need separate arrangements.
bullets: Provider: AnchorWatch Inc. (US) with Lloyd's syndicate backing
Can be compelled: Policy details · Compliance notes · Communication logs
Can't access: Customer-held keys · Offline recovery phrases
Complaints: Arch Insurance (US) or Lloyd's (UK) escalation paths
tiles.explainer_summary: What if a court wants to freeze funds?
tiles.explainer_text: AnchorWatch can refuse to sign or alert you if a lawful order arrives, but they cannot move funds without your key. You decide whether to cooperate or move funds via the recovery path.

tiles.title: Your controls
tiles.benefit: Review anytime Export or delete
tiles.why: Insurance-grade recordkeeping still gives you transparency so you can right-size what AnchorWatch stores.
tiles.summary: The Trident portal keeps every signature request, descriptor update, and beneficiary change in one log so you never lose track. Data export and deletion workflows live in the same place, so you can keep only what regulators require.
bullets: Portal access: Download policy docs, descriptors, and transaction logs whenever needed
Notifications: Customize incident and signature alerts for email, SMS, or phone
Data requests: Submit export/delete tickets once retention obligations end
Audit trail: Every support touch is logged for SOC and insurance reviews
tiles.explainer_text: Insurance rules require keeping KYC and claim files for statutory periods (often 5–7 years). AnchorWatch deletes or returns data after that window if you ask.

micro_faqs.q: What personal data does AnchorWatch store?
micro_faqs.a: They keep KYC/KYB packets, policy paperwork, and compliance evidence but never your private keys.

micro_faqs.q: Can I monitor the vault without AnchorWatch?
micro_faqs.a: Yes. Use the output descriptor with your own node or explorer to verify balances independently.

micro_faqs.q: How do I request data deletion?
micro_faqs.a: Email support with your policy number once statutory retention periods expire, and they purge or return the files.

glossary.def: Monthly charge that funds custody tech, compliance support, and the AnchorWatch signer infrastructure.
Descriptor plus instructions that let you spend directly via Bitcoin Core if AnchorWatch is offline.
Insurance category AnchorWatch uses to cover physical assets like bitcoin held in cold storage.

cards.fact: Trident vaults and code audited by Halborn, Doyensec, and Blockstream cryptographers.
Insurance policies are 100% backed by Lloyd's of London A+ rated syndicates.
Privacy policy explains how KYC, compliance, and complaint data are handled in the US.
Terms, complaints, and Arch Insurance contacts are published for policyholders.
